practicalInformation.title: Weather advice
practicalInformation.description: Light clothing for summer, coats for winter in the north, and comfortable shoes for walking in historic towns.

dos: Greet with a handshake or cheek kisses depending on familiarity.
Dress smartly — Italians value appearance and style.
Respect meal times and enjoy food slowly.
Learn basic Italian phrases; locals appreciate the effort.
Respect churches by dressing modestly when visiting.
Participate in social traditions like evening passeggiata.
donts: Don’t order cappuccino after 11 a.m. — it’s considered a breakfast drink.
Don’t eat pizza with ketchup or alter traditional dishes.
Don’t talk loudly in churches or sacred sites.
Don’t skip greetings — always say 'Buongiorno' when entering shops or restaurants.
Don’t expect punctuality at social events (a little lateness is common).
Don’t assume all Italians eat the same food — regional cuisines vary greatly.

name: China

about.description: China, officially the People’s Republic of China (PRC), is the world’s most populous country and the fourth-largest by area, located in East Asia. It shares borders with 14 countries including India, Russia, and Mongolia. With thousands of years of history, China is known as one of the world’s oldest continuous civilizations, influencing philosophy, science, technology, literature, and art. Its capital is Beijing, while major cities include Shanghai (financial hub), Guangzhou (manufacturing center), and Shenzhen (technology hub).
about.Languages: Mandarin Chinese (Putonghua) is the official language, but China has 55 recognized ethnic minorities who speak their own languages and dialects (e.g., Cantonese, Tibetan, Uighur, Mongolian, Hakka).
about.Population: Over 1.4 billion people, making it the most populous country in the world, with diverse ethnic groups such as Han (majority), Zhuang, Hui, Tibetan, Uyghur, and Mongol.
about.Climate: China has diverse climates — arid deserts in the northwest, monsoon regions in the south, temperate zones in the east, and harsh winters in the north and Tibetan plateau. Summers are hot and humid in many regions, while winters vary from mild in the south to freezing in the north.
about.Government: A socialist one-party state governed by the Communist Party of China (CPC). The President is head of state and the Premier is head of government.
about.Currency: Renminbi (RMB), commonly known as the Yuan (¥).
about.Famous: The Great Wall of China, Terracotta Army, Chinese New Year, martial arts (Kung Fu, Tai Chi), Chinese medicine, calligraphy, silk, tea, pandas, Confucianism, Taoism, inventions like paper, compass, printing, and gunpowder.

greetings: The common greeting is 'Nǐ hǎo' (你好) meaning 'Hello'.
Handshakes are increasingly common in business settings, but traditionally people greet with a slight bow or nod.
Titles are important — addressing people by family name followed by a title (e.g., 'Wang Laoshi' for Teacher Wang) shows respect.
It’s polite to acknowledge elders first when greeting a group.
Physical affection in greetings is rare — hugs and cheek kisses are uncommon.
Politeness is shown through modesty, respectful tone, and avoiding overly direct refusals.
Exchanging business cards with both hands is a sign of respect.
academic: Education is highly competitive and exam-oriented, especially with the National College Entrance Examination (Gaokao).
Teachers hold great respect, and classrooms are often disciplined and formal.
Memorization and hard work are emphasized, though creativity and innovation are increasingly encouraged.
Grading usually follows a percentage system (0–100) with 60 as the passing mark.
Universities in China include world-class institutions like Tsinghua University and Peking University.
STEM subjects, engineering, and business studies are highly valued.
Campus life includes clubs, sports, and cultural associations, though academic pressure remains strong.
dailyLife: Family is central in daily life — respect for parents and grandparents is rooted in Confucian traditions.
Many families practice multi-generational living under one roof.
Meals are often shared from common dishes, eaten with chopsticks.
Breakfast is usually savory (e.g., steamed buns, congee, dumplings) instead of sweet.
Public transport is highly developed — subways, buses, and high-speed trains are widely used.
Work and study schedules can be intense, especially in urban centers.
In rural areas, daily life often revolves around agriculture and community activities.

festival.title: Chinese New Year (Spring Festival)
festival.description: The most important festival, celebrated with family reunions, red decorations, dragon dances, fireworks, and giving red envelopes (hóngbāo).

festival.title: Mid-Autumn Festival
festival.description: Celebrated with mooncakes and family gatherings, honoring the full moon and reunion.

festival.title: Dragon Boat Festival
festival.description: Marked by dragon boat races and eating sticky rice dumplings (zongzi) in memory of poet Qu Yuan.

festival.title: Lantern Festival
festival.description: Celebrated on the 15th day of the Lunar New Year with lantern displays, riddles, and glutinous rice balls (tāngyuán).

festival.title: National Day (October 1)
festival.description: Marks the founding of the PRC with parades, fireworks, and patriotic events.

festival.title: Qingming Festival (Tomb-Sweeping Day)
festival.description: Families honor ancestors by cleaning graves and making offerings.

festival.title: Double Seventh Festival (Qixi)
festival.description: Known as Chinese Valentine’s Day, celebrating the legendary love story of the cowherd and the weaver girl.

lifestyle.title: Housing
lifestyle.description: High-rise apartments dominate urban areas, while traditional courtyard houses (siheyuan) and rural homes remain in villages.

lifestyle.title: Food habits
lifestyle.description: Chinese cuisine varies greatly by region — spicy Sichuan dishes, Cantonese dim sum, northern noodles, and southern rice-based meals. Tea culture is deeply ingrained.

lifestyle.title: Work-life balance
lifestyle.description: Work culture in cities can be demanding (the '996' schedule: 9 a.m. to 9 p.m., six days a week). Weekends and public holidays are valued for family gatherings.

lifestyle.title: Shopping
lifestyle.description: China leads in e-commerce, with platforms like Taobao, JD.com, and Pinduoduo. Street markets and malls coexist with online shopping.

lifestyle.title: Health & wellness
lifestyle.description: Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) — acupuncture, herbal remedies, and Tai Chi — coexists with modern healthcare.

lifestyle.title: Transportation
lifestyle.description: China has the world’s largest high-speed rail network. Bicycles and electric scooters are common in cities.

socialConnections: Family bonds are central; filial piety (respect for parents and elders) is a core value.
Friendships are built gradually, often through shared meals and trust.
Business relationships rely on 'guanxi' (personal connections and networks).
Marriage and family remain important, though dating culture is growing among younger generations.
Group activities such as karaoke (KTV), mahjong, and shared meals are popular.
Social media platforms like WeChat and Weibo are dominant for communication and networking.
Hospitality is shown by offering food, tea, and gifts during visits.

practicalInformation.title: Currency
practicalInformation.description: Renminbi (RMB ¥). Notes include denominations up to ¥100; mobile payments (WeChat Pay, Alipay) are more common than cash.

practicalInformation.title: Transport
practicalInformation.description: Extensive metro systems in major cities. High-speed trains connect regions efficiently. Taxis and ride-hailing apps like Didi are widely used.

practicalInformation.title: Banking
practicalInformation.description: Digital wallets dominate daily life; traditional banking is also available but less used for small payments.

practicalInformation.title: Healthcare
practicalInformation.description: Public healthcare is available, but many opt for private hospitals for quicker services. Insurance is common for expats.

practicalInformation.title: Emergency numbers
practicalInformation.description: 110 for police, 120 for ambulance, 119 for fire, 122 for traffic accidents.

practicalInformation.title: Mobile/Internet
practicalInformation.description: Internet is regulated (Great Firewall). Google, Facebook, and YouTube are blocked, but local platforms like Baidu, WeChat, and TikTok (Douyin) thrive.

practicalInformation.title: Weather advice
practicalInformation.description: Pack according to region — heavy coats for northern winters, light clothes for humid summers, and rain gear during monsoons.

dos: Use both hands when giving or receiving something, especially gifts or business cards.
Show respect to elders and superiors in speech and behavior.
Be punctual for meetings and formal gatherings.
Try local dishes and show appreciation for Chinese food culture.
Learn basic Mandarin phrases; effort in language is valued.
Participate politely in traditions, such as toasting during meals.
donts: Don’t stick chopsticks upright in rice — it resembles funeral offerings.
Don’t give clocks, white flowers, or sharp objects as gifts — they symbolize bad luck.
Don’t openly criticize Chinese politics or government.
Don’t write names in red ink — it is associated with death.
Don’t touch someone’s head — it is considered disrespectful.
Don’t point directly with your finger; use your whole hand instead.

name: UK

about.description: The United Kingdom (UK), officially the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, is located in northwestern Europe. It comprises four nations — England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. London is the capital and global financial hub. The UK is famous for its historic monarchy, diverse culture, and global influence in politics, science, literature, and music. Landmarks like Big Ben, Buckingham Palace, and Stonehenge are world-renowned.
about.Languages: English is the official and primary language. Regional languages include Welsh (Wales), Scottish Gaelic (Scotland), and Irish (Northern Ireland). Immigrant communities also speak Punjabi, Urdu, Arabic, and Polish.
about.Population: Approximately 67 million people. The population is highly diverse due to centuries of immigration and multiculturalism.
about.Climate: Mild temperate climate. Winters are cool and wet (0–8°C), summers are mild (15–25°C). Rainfall is common throughout the year. Snowfall occurs occasionally in northern and hilly regions.
about.Government: A constitutional monarchy with a parliamentary democracy. The monarch is the ceremonial head of state, while the Prime Minister leads the government.
about.Famous: Royal Family, afternoon tea, football (soccer), Shakespeare, The Beatles, Harry Potter, universities like Oxford & Cambridge, double-decker buses, red phone boxes, and fish & chips.

greetings: Handshakes are the most common form of greeting in formal and professional settings.
In casual settings, people often greet with a simple 'Hello,' 'Hi,' or 'How are you?'
First names are used widely, though titles and surnames are used in very formal situations.
Politeness is key — phrases like 'please,' 'thank you,' and 'sorry' are used frequently.
People generally respect personal space and avoid physical contact with strangers.
Small talk about weather, sports, or weekend plans is a common way to break the ice.
academic: The UK has one of the world’s most respected education systems, with renowned universities like Oxford, Cambridge, and the London School of Economics.
Classroom culture encourages critical thinking, debate, and independent learning.
Students address teachers formally (Mr., Ms., Dr., or Professor), though relationships are friendly.
Assignments, essays, and research projects are key components of grading.
Assessment methods include coursework, exams, presentations, and group projects.
International students often receive support services to adapt to UK academic culture.
Extracurricular activities such as sports, debate clubs, and arts societies are very popular.
dailyLife: Punctuality is highly valued — being late is considered rude.
Tea culture is strong; many people enjoy tea breaks during the day.
Public transport is widely used — especially the London Underground (Tube), buses, and trains.
Queuing (standing in line) is taken very seriously and seen as a sign of politeness.
People generally dress according to the weather, with coats and umbrellas being essentials.
Work-life balance is important; weekends are often spent with family, sports, or leisure.
Pub culture is a big part of social life, though also inclusive of dining and socializing.

festival.title: Christmas (December 25)
festival.description: The most celebrated holiday, with family gatherings, gift exchanges, church services, and festive meals including roast turkey and Christmas pudding.

festival.title: Easter
festival.description: Celebrated with church services, chocolate eggs, parades, and traditions like the Easter Bunny.

festival.title: Bonfire Night (November 5)
festival.description: Also called Guy Fawkes Night, marked with fireworks, bonfires, and traditional snacks.

festival.title: St. Patrick’s Day (March 17)
festival.description: Especially popular in Northern Ireland, celebrated with parades, music, and green-themed events.

festival.title: Notting Hill Carnival
festival.description: One of Europe’s biggest street festivals in London, celebrating Caribbean culture with music, costumes, and dance.

festival.title: Remembrance Day (November 11)
festival.description: Honors soldiers who died in wars, marked with a two-minute silence and poppy symbols.

festival.title: New Year’s Eve
festival.description: Celebrated with fireworks, especially in London along the Thames, and the famous countdown at Big Ben.

lifestyle.title: Housing
lifestyle.description: Urban housing includes flats, terraced houses, and student accommodations. In rural areas, cottages and detached homes are common.

lifestyle.title: Food habits
lifestyle.description: Traditional dishes include fish & chips, roast dinners, and full English breakfasts. International cuisines like Indian, Chinese, and Italian are very popular.

lifestyle.title: Work-life balance
lifestyle.description: A strong focus on balancing career and leisure. Employees typically work 35–40 hours per week with holidays and paid leave.

lifestyle.title: Shopping
lifestyle.description: High streets, supermarkets, and shopping centers are common. Online shopping via Amazon, ASOS, and Tesco is widespread.

lifestyle.title: Health & wellness
lifestyle.description: The National Health Service (NHS) provides free healthcare to residents. Fitness culture includes gyms, jogging, and sports.

lifestyle.title: Transportation
lifestyle.description: The UK has extensive public transport. Driving is on the left side of the road. Bicycles are common in cities like Cambridge and Oxford.

socialConnections: Friendships often develop in schools, universities, or workplaces.
People enjoy socializing in pubs, cafes, or through sports clubs.
Family values remain important, though individual independence is also highly respected.
Dating culture is open, and people may meet through apps, social events, or friends.
Volunteerism and charity work are widespread forms of community engagement.
Sports, especially football, cricket, and rugby, are a big part of social life.

practicalInformation.title: Currency
practicalInformation.description: British Pound Sterling (£, GBP). Common coins include 1p to £2; notes range from £5 to £50.

practicalInformation.title: Transport
practicalInformation.description: Buses, trains, and the London Underground are widely used. Students can get discounted travel passes.

practicalInformation.title: Banking
practicalInformation.description: Contactless payments and debit/credit cards are widely accepted. Mobile banking is common.

practicalInformation.title: Healthcare
practicalInformation.description: The NHS provides public healthcare, though private healthcare options also exist.

practicalInformation.title: Emergency numbers
practicalInformation.description: Dial 999 for police, ambulance, or fire services. 111 is for non-emergency medical advice.

practicalInformation.title: Mobile/Internet
practicalInformation.description: Reliable 4G/5G networks with providers like Vodafone, O2, EE, and Three. Wi-Fi is common in homes and public spaces.

practicalInformation.title: Weather advice
practicalInformation.description: Rain is frequent — carrying an umbrella is essential. Winters require coats, scarves, and gloves.

dos: Do stand in queues patiently.
Do greet people politely with 'Hello' or 'Hi'.
Do respect personal space and privacy.
Do arrive on time for meetings and appointments.
Do try traditional British food and afternoon tea.
Do engage in small talk, especially about weather or sports.
donts: Don’t cut in queues — it is considered very rude.
Don’t be overly loud in public places.
Don’t make jokes about the monarchy or sensitive political issues.
Don’t invade personal space — British people value privacy.
Don’t forget to say 'please' and 'thank you' — politeness is expected.
Don’t assume everyone has the same accent or traditions — the UK is diverse.
